comment_body.6:
I dont really know how i would incorporate the template so please dont kill me.

Hello everyone, so recently I sold my first car (my 99 GTP coupe) that was my summer car, I took really good care of it but I got tired of automatic... So now I'm left with my daily (2000 Civic) that runs flawlessly but leaks a ton of oil on the driveway, which pisses off my dad.

I'm torn because I love retro cars, and the 86-88 Fiero GT is my all-time favorite. And since retro cars are shooting up in value for good examples, I really want to snag a good Fiero when I can for a reasonable price. Keeping my civic as my daily/winter and to have the Fiero as a fun summer car.

My parents and my brother disagree, they think I should sell my civic and buy something newer like a BRZ/Civic SI that I can drive all year round, avoiding dumping money into older vehicles (Not that I don't have the money, they see it as a waste.

Keep in mind, I live in Ontario Canada, so I need a car to take me from work to home, even if my work ends up being all the way up in Alliston Ontario. Would my little 2000 civic be able to handle that or should I take the safe route and buy something newer?

TLDR: Should I buy a Fiero and keep using my old civic as a daily or be safe and buy something newer?

What do you guys think? If you need any more info please chime in. Thanks!

comment_body.45:
Torn between a Jeep Wrangler 4xe and Toyota Tacoma TRD Off Road.

Tacoma Pros:

  • Low depreciation

  • Bed. Specifically I reserved one with a 6' long box.

  • Towing capacity over 6000 lbs

  • $40k price point

Tacoma cons:

  • Cramped interior. It's tolerable, but not large.

  • No heated seats or automatic climate control.

  • Back sears are not comfy.

  • Shit fuel economy

  • Not much "fun" or "cool" factor

Jeep pros:

  • Also low depreciation

  • Found a dealer that will sell 10% below MSRP

  • $7500 tax credit

  • Rubicon trim is undoubtedly better for offroading (both will do more than I ever need)

  • More power and torque than Tacoma

  • Much more comfortable interior with more luxury features

  • 90% of my driving could be done without using gas

  • It's a fucking convertible. Way more fun to drive than Tacoma.

Jeep cons:

  • $57k for a loaded Rubicon ($50k after tax break)

  • 3500lb towing capacity is enough for utility trailers and not much more

  • First-year reliability

  • Potentially faster than expected depreciation?

I'm basically looking for someone to talk me out of reserving a Rubicon 4xe, but it seems too hard to talk myself out of it.

comment_body.106: Toyota and Honda CVTs are bulletproof as long as you change the fluid frequently (20-30k). Early (and maybe current?) Nissan CVTs had a poor design and did not specify a frequent enough fluid change in their maintenance schedules which is why they grenaded. Mazda3 is the only car in the segment that you're gonna get w/o a CVT, but that shouldn't be the driving factor in your decision. They are considered the most fun to drive in the segment though and are quite reliable, so it's a good pick.
comment_body.107: Most auto Civics use CVT these days. You should look for a Mazda 3, though make sure you pay attention to which transmission it has as some could involve a CVT.
